text: pudding is one of those things that is
so nostalgic to me I remember loving it
so much as a kid I thought it would be
fun to share with you our test kitchens
easy way of making homemade vanilla or
chocolate pudding from scratch so I'm
starting with two thirds of a cup of
granulated sugar straight into the
medium pot over the burner here this is
kind of like our easy way to make pastry
cream without tempering eggs so I'm
adding a quarter of a cup of cornstarch
to the sugar a quarter teaspoon of salt
and a third of a cup of cocoa powder
because I'm going to be making chocolate
today if you wanted to keep this as
vanilla pudding you can just omit the
cocoa powder but I love chocolate so
that's my choice so I'll just whisk
these together and add two and a half
cups of whole milk you want to do this
fairly slowly I usually start with a
couple of tablespoons and whisk it
together until it's almost like a paste
and then keep adding a little bit at a
time by doing this I'm getting rid of
all of the lumps that you might find if
you add the liquid too quickly I think
you can add the rest of it in here
scrape around the sides a little bit and
now I'm adding four egg yolks this is
from large eggs now everyone seems to
have different little tricks for
separating yolks and whites I just do it
the old-fashioned way but whatever works
for you is great so now into the pot our
yolks go sure they're completely whisked
in there and doing all of this off heat
so now that this is all combined I'm
going to put this onto medium heat and
whisk it constantly until it starts
bubbling if you wanted to keep this
vanilla pudding it could be really nice
to add some fresh vanilla bean and then
you just strain it out at the end then
you get that really intense delicious
vanilla flavor and I'm doing this over
medium heat so you really make sure that
you don't scorch anything on the bottom
the egg yolks can curdle so that's why
it's important to keep whisking low and
slow try not to be impatient here
because you'll have the best product in
the air as I mentioned I really loved
putting as a kid my mom even has a
picture of me when I was 1 year old
sitting in a highchair absolutely
covered head-to-toe in chocolate pudding
I clearly thought it was face paint I
smeared it everywhere but I've surely
was born to be a pastry cooks because I
have always loved chocolate see how the
steam coming up starting to bubble
you'll feel it with your whisk too
you'll definitely know and don't be
alarmed at this stage because some parts
may start thickening faster than others
that's okay it will all whisk together
and become smooth all right so now it is
bubbling and once you see these spurts
start your timer for one minute and keep
whisking as it bubbles for one minute
all right so it's been a minute this is
thickened it's glossy it smells like hot
chocolate and I'm ready to strain this
see these handles are hot always touch
them first to make sure that you're not
going to burn yourself you can pour this
straight into the sieve this is really
nice because it should be smooth but
just in case there are any little lumps
of egg in there the sieve will catch all
of them everything out now just pass
this through the sieve it'll collect any
lumps that might have formed from the
egg it's really steamy great don't
forget all that good stuff down
underneath and now we mix in two
tablespoons of butter that's been cut
into small pieces that just helps it
melt this adds a really great luscious
mouthfeel to your pudding makes it super
glossy all rage the butter is just about
melted and finally one teaspoon of
vanilla extract because my opinion
vanilla always just makes desserts taste
extra delicious
and good so I'm just going to wrap this
up by putting plastic directly on the
surface of the pudding
this helps prevent it from getting that
skin that sometimes forms on the top of
pudding when it chills some people like
that I'm not the biggest fan so I like
to put the plastic directly on the
surface and now this is going into the
fridge for at least three hours until
it's cool and up to three days so the
pudding is chilled and we are ready to
serve take the plastic off you just want
to give it a nice whisk to loosen it up
just because it gets kind of stiff in
the fridge smooth creamy just what you
want in a pudding now we're ready to dig
in so I would just spoon this into your
serving ramekins bowls if you're
enjoying this video be sure to LIKE

many delicious things for you to make
